Posts.Content: Originally Posted by caddy2507 I've had this dibble when on the toilet with my catheter in as well. In my experience, nothing to worry about. It seems that when sitting to have a bowel movement that the catheter can move slightly up or to the side which causes a leak down the side of the tube. My catheter is out (since about 2 1/2 weeks) and I'm fine! Was going to go have it checked out...but maybe I'll leaving for now. Although for some reason it burns like a son of a gun whenever it happens. Thanks..
Posts.Title: Catheter leak while on toilet

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Semiramide Catheter leak while on toilet = a good place to be when catheter springs a leak! Things will be better after catheter is removed Thanks for the info...I may have just been freaking out because the Dr. gave us some literature to read and it mentioned to go to hospital if you notice leaking! Another thing I read here online last night was...you're not supposed to do keigels if you have a catheter. Man I've been doing Keigels like a banshee!
Posts.Title: Catheter leak while on toilet

Posts.Content: Hi All, Just wondering if any of you have had leakage around the catheter while having or attempting to have a bowel movement. Also, very sharp burning sensation at the same time! The catheter seems to work good all other times...just not then. I'll mention again...I just have my RALP 8 days ago.
Posts.Title: Catheter leak while on toilet

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Had a small leak once or twice with bowel movement. Nothing to write home about (oh, wait, you are home), just keep up the stool softeners so you don't strain. For burning you can ask your doc if it's OK to take OTC phenazopyridine (Azo) or s/he can Rx the prescription strength. It's a non-opioid urinary analgesic. I found it helped the first couple of weeks with urethral burning and discomfort. Don't get scared, it turns urine bright orange. Thanks...I will ask the doctor about that tomorrow. I thought to cover bases I best go and see him. The problem this morning was that...normally I would have one or two drops dribble while on the toilet...but today there was a lot coming out. Yet nothing while walking or sitting or even lying down...weird!

Posts.Title: Catheter leak while on toilet

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind If this is becoming a real problem, they make catheters in different sizes. By moving up to the next larger size, the problem should stop..But by the time you can have this done, you will be ready for removal anyway.. Thanks...that's exactly what I was thinking. Just as long as no harm can happen...I'm ok with it!

Posts.Title: Catheter leak while on toilet

Posts.Content: Not sure how things work in the US...but in Canada you have to declare any pre existing conditions you may have. The minute they find out (and they will) that you forgot to declare for example "high blood pressure" they can and will void any claims. I would ask about that with your insurance company as well. What it means is...if you were to trap and break your leg and you never declared you had prostate cancer...your claim would be void!
Posts.Title: Travel insurance

Posts.Content: This issue was probably already touched on...but can anyone tell me how being diagnosed with PC would affect travel health insurance. Also...once you've had surgery to remove the prostate and you're declared cancer free (fingers crossed)...do you still have to mention it to the insurance company?
Posts.Title: Travel insurance

Posts.Content: Not sure how things work in the US...but in Canada you have to declare any pre existing conditions you may have. The minute they find out (and they will) that you forgot to declare for example "high blood pressure" they can and will void any claims. I would ask about that with your insurance company as well. What it means is...if you were to trap and break your leg and you never declared you had prostate cancer...your claim would be void!
Posts.Title: Travel insurance

Also...once you've had surgery to remove the prostate and you're declared cancer free (fingers crossed)...do you still have to mention it to the insurance company?
Posts.Title: Travel insurance

Posts.Content: Being from Canada with our crappy health care...I paid zero dollar...zero deductable. No private hospital room mind you...but to share a room for two nights didn't kill me. Btw...the crappy health care was being sarcastic...I believe we have excellent health care here in Canada. I just love it when I hear Trump dissing our HC
Posts.Title: RALP...Nobody ever discussed costs ! What are they ?

Posts.Content: Great news caddy...celebrate...you deserve it! My results will be in Dec 18 and I'm hope for the same?..all the best!
Posts.Title: First PSA Test after RP

Posts.Content: Great news caddy...celebrate...you deserve it! My results will be in Dec 18 and I'm hope for the same?..all the best!
Posts.Title: First PSA Test after RP

Posts.Content: Good news jd...enjoy your retirement and the rest of your life!
Posts.Title: Still a Member

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider When I spoke to the surgeon myself, he said he had patients ready to return to work after surgery within a fortnight. I think if you are in general good health, you should be ok, but just mark the date in pencil so you will be prepared if there are any complications. My wife and I have been planning to spend our winters (we live in Alberta) for several years now and every year something came up to prevent us from going down for any extended period. This was the year where we said that no matter what...we're going. Then I had this diagnosis in the spring and thought...maybe if all goes well we can still salvage most of the trip. I was mostly concerned about the 3 days in the saddle on the way down and any post op issues that could arise. It will be 5+ weeks after the surgery and I'm keeping my fingers cross all goes well. Better in diapers in California than -30 degrees in Alberta! Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH It probably differs from doctor to doctor -- and also from case to case -- but the general timespan between surgery and the first PSA test is around 90 days. Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I gave you your very own thread to get more replies for you. I would think that 4+ weeks after surgery you would be able to do some traveling. You will still have to be very careful, though, as the healing will still be taking place. Would you be back home in time for your first post-op PSA test? Originally Posted by Another Would not have been a problem for me. Your details are important. If there's bad news it could put a lot of stress on things. Incontinence could be stressful dealing with diapers or pads for the first time if it occurs. It took 3 months for me to return to normal. This can go so many ways that it really depends on how resilent you are. This isn't like getting a vasectomy or your tonsils removed. I returned to work in 5 days. I did because I had to. My productivity was way down. A vacation could work if it's a relaxing low stress one. Like lying on the beach. If it's a forced march type of trip it's doable, but why?
Posts.Title: How long after surgery can I travel?

Posts.Content: Hopefully the only lifting will be the gas nozzle and my wallet...we are planning on taking our RV south. I have AMA in case of break down or flat tire...so no lifting there.
Posts.Title: How long after surgery can I travel?

Posts.Content: Sorry to pipe in on this thread...but I am having my prostate removed Oct.23 and was wondering a little about recovery time. I know all about the catheter and roughly how long I may need it. I'm just wondering approx. how long it may take on avaerage to be able to travel by ran for some distance? My wife and I wanted to go to California this winter and we're planning on leaving November 27 is that too soon?
Posts.Title: How long after surgery can I travel?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I gave you your very own thread to get more replies for you. I would think that 4+ weeks after surgery you would be able to do some traveling. You will still have to be very careful, though, as the healing will still be taking place. Would you be back home in time for your first post-op PSA test? Thanks for doing that! I will be home for 5 weeks post surgery and can certainly fly home for any follow ups as needed (as long as there's seat sales)...just kidding! Typically how long after surgery would they do another PSA test?
Posts.Title: How long after surgery can I travel?

Posts.Content: Hopefully the only lifting will be the gas nozzle and my wallet...we are planning on taking our RV south. I have AMA in case of break down or flat tire...so no lifting there.

Posts.Title: How long after surgery can I travel?

Posts.Content: Hey TP, I was like you...every time I stood for the first week after the catheter was removed I'd leak a bit. Slowly that will disappear over time and I found if I concentrated on holding it whenever I would stand...that helped. I'm six weeks post surgery as of yesterday and about the only time I leak is if I have a big sneeze and forget to focus on holding it. Even then it's a tiny little dribble and not a lot to worry about. I would say the Keigels help a ton...so try to do them at least two or three times a day and most of all...be patient! Sounds to me like you're making excellent progress.
Posts.Title: 2 weeks post RALP , 4 days post catheter

Posts.Content: Hey TP, I was like you...every time I stood for the first week after the catheter was removed I'd leak a bit. Slowly that will disappear over time and I found if I concentrated on holding it whenever I would stand...that helped. I'm six weeks post surgery as of yesterday and about the only time I leak is if I have a big sneeze and forget to focus on holding it. Even then it's a tiny little dribble and not a lot to worry about. I would say the Keigels help a ton...so try to do them at least two or three times a day and most of all...be patient! Sounds to me like you're making excellent progress.
Posts.Title: 2 weeks post RALP , 4 days post catheter

Posts.Content: Thanks fishing...sounds like what happened in my case as well...happened right after a bowl movement. I'll keep an eye on it!
Posts.Title: Day 5 Post RALP

Posts.Content: Hey guys, I can't say enough about this forum and all of the people who generously give there time to post things about there experiences and the valuable information that helped me decide what direction I wanted to go....and for that I am truly grateful...thank you! Had surgery Monday 7:30am and a few hours later woke up in post op. For a guy who never spend any time in a hospital it was quite an eye and ear opener. The nursing staff and all of the doctors were absolutely amazing...always kind and thoughtful of what you went through and I can't say enough about them and the U of A hospital! One thing I found out very soon was...you don't get much "rest" at the hospital. There is a constant chatter and traffic in and out of the rooms is non stop....so if you're a light sleeper like myself...go luck sleeping! As far as pain and discomfort goes...the first day and night after surgery were a little difficult. Day 2 was somewhat better and was able to walk about and even went outside for a stroll. Day 3 was instruction day from nurse and out the door we went...leg catheter on and ready to do the 1 hr trek home. We did have to pull over on a side road once to empty the bag (to much water that morning) but everything came out just fine. Beautiful wife made me a delicious bowl of soup..watched the Astros beat the Dodgers and off for a ten hour well needed sleep. Day 4 amazing just how a great nights sleep can improve your overall attitude...I highly recommend it! Still taking a few Tramacets once or twice a day for the discomfort..but I can see those gone by the weekend. I was fortunate enough to have a bowl movement the very next morning of the surgery and every morning since...but I did notice a small amount of leakage from where the catheter enters the penis. Is this something I should be alarmed with?
Posts.Title: Day 5 Post RALP

Posts.Content: Thanks fishing...sounds like what happened in my case as well...happened right after a bowl movement. I'll keep an eye on it!

I was fortunate enough to have a bowl movement the very next morning of the surgery and every morning since...but I did notice a small amount of leakage from where the catheter enters the penis. Is this something I should be alarmed with?
Posts.Title: Day 5 Post RALP

Posts.Content: Hey guys, I can't say enough about this forum and all of the people who generously give there time to post things about there experiences and the valuable information that helped me decide what direction I wanted to go....and for that I am truly grateful...thank you! Had surgery Monday 7:30am and a few hours later woke up in post op. For a guy who never spend any time in a hospital it was quite an eye and ear opener. The nursing staff and all of the doctors were absolutely amazing...always kind and thoughtful of what you went through and I can't say enough about them and the U of A hospital! One thing I found out very soon was...you don't get much "rest" at the hospital. There is a constant chatter and traffic in and out of the rooms is non stop....so if you're a light sleeper like myself...go luck sleeping! As far as pain and discomfort goes...the first day and night after surgery were a little difficult. Day 2 was somewhat better and was able to walk about and even went outside for a stroll. Day 3 was instruction day from nurse and out the door we went...leg catheter on and ready to do the 1 hr trek home. We did have to pull over on a side road once to empty the bag (to much water that morning) but everything came out just fine. Beautiful wife made me a delicious bowl of soup..watched the Astros beat the Dodgers and off for a ten hour well needed sleep. Day 4 amazing just how a great nights sleep can improve your overall attitude...I highly recommend it! Still taking a few Tramacets once or twice a day for the discomfort..but I can see those gone by the weekend. I was fortunate enough to have a bowl movement the very next morning of the surgery and every morning since...but I did notice a small amount of leakage from where the catheter enters the penis. Is this something I should be alarmed with?
Posts.Title: Day 5 Post RALP

Posts.Content: Thanks fishing...sounds like what happened in my case as well...happened right after a bowl movement. I'll keep an eye on it!

Posts.Title: Day 5 Post RALP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MRJ Gerd-- Great news! Now just to help my inner OCD, please point the arrow to the left so it reads less than. ">0.1" change this to "<0.1" Ooops...my mistake...it was very early in the am!
Posts.Title: Great news...with a catch!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tropicisland I had my prostate removed June 28 2017 and both nerve are spared. I am cialis 100mg I started cialis 10mg 1 month after surgery and nothing but headache. I went to my doctor within 1 month and said I need my prostate back. He told to take 100mg and still nothing is happening. It been over 6 months now. I guess it with get some blood in there maybe the next 6 months??? This might not be for everyone...but a little soft porn and masterbation can go a long way in your ED recovery. Your wife will thank you later!
Posts.Title: No erection

Posts.Content: Hey TP Sounds like everything is going as it should. I agree about the two night recovery in the hospital aside from how noisey it can be and the lack of sleep. I sure made up for it on the first night home and slept for almost ten hours...nothing beats your own bed at home! You should have your appetite back in no time at all...just watch you don't over eat...that can certainly cause you a lot of discomfort as I found out. As much as the catheter is a pain in the ass...the time you have it goes by very quickly and next thing you know it's getting yanked out! I had mine in for two weeks because the doctor said they like to see things heal up inside real well before pulling it out. It must have worked for me...my incontinence only lasted a few days and I was dry all night from day one. I wear a light pad just for the odd dribble....but aside from that I feel 95% after 30 days. I also lost approx. 15 lbs so don't be alarmed if you loose weight...sometimes it's a good thing! Best of luck to you and have a speedy recovery!

Posts.Title: 3rd morning post RALP surgery

Posts.Content: WOW TP...what a relief that must be for you! Congrats to you and your wife...whom if she's anything like my wife...did enough to worrying for the both of us! On to the next chapter...living life to the fullest!
Posts.Title: Post Surgery report back tpjames

Posts.Content: For my RALP I came to this forum to see what the criteria should be for choosing the perfect surgeon. Most of the comments suggested to look for one that had the most notches on his belt which immediately ruled out my surgeon. My surgeon (Dr. Jacobsen Kaye clinic Edmonton) is one of those guys that you feel comfortable with from the moment you meet him. I asked him how many RALP operations he's performed and he checked and said 350...not a high number compared to most. But he was straight about doing everything possible when it came to nerve sparing and my percentages regarding incontinence and ED. He made me feel very comfortable in his knowledge and ability to do everything possible that I can live a normal health life after the surgery. I truly believe he delivered on his promise and aside from the odd dribble...I feel 90% back to normal after only 3 weeks. And not to sound perverse...watching a steamy scene in a movie last night...I was actually a bit aroused. A good sign indeed! My opinion...go with the guy or gal you feel most comfortable with!
Posts.Title: Criteria for choosing Surgeon

Posts.Content: Merry Christmas JJ I had my surgery exactly two months ago and my wife and I were both super positive that we made the right decision going with the RALP. My Gleason score was pretty much what yours was....and as my surgeon explained it to us, "you can wait, but sooner or later we'll be getting together" We thought why not get it done while I was healthy and in a positive mood about the whole thing. My surgeon thought most likely the cancer was localized in the prostate, so it just made sense to remove it all together. As much as there is a bit of pain and discomfort for the first couple of weeks...I found after that I felt almost as good as before I went in. That in itself was an odd feeling going in for surgery when you feel 100% inside and out...but knowing the cancer will be gone makes the entire ordeal worth it. You made the right decision and you'll be better for it...Just think cancer free New Year's Eve!
Posts.Title: Merry Christmas, RALP now 4 days away

Posts.Content: Had my 8 week post op check with my surgeon yesterday afternoon and the first thing out of his mouth was "ZERO PSA" my wife and I were so happy we wanted to cry. Then as the conversation went on...he began to explain how the operation went well but the results from the lab showed that some of the cancer was very near the base of the prostate. This being said...he felt most likely isolated to the prostate, but there is a chance it snuck out...and that's the catch! Amazing how your elation can turn into confusion in the matter of minutes. Anyway...he said not to worry that in the off chance there is something...it can be treated! So now it's a wait and see situation. I'm still happy with the >0.1 so Merry Christmas to all of you and may your days be Merry and Bright!
Posts.Title: Great news...with a catch!

Posts.Title: No erection

Posts.Content: Hey, Thanks for all of the positive feed back guys...it's very encouraging to hear all of your comments. I'm certainly not dwelling on the "but" part of the report...I'm trying to focus more on the "you no longer have prostate cancer" portion. And as much as yesterday felt like a bit of a let down...today the positive attitude kicked in and I'm paddling the right direction now! Thanks again and Happy Holidays which ever way you celebrate!

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas, RALP now 4 days away

Posts.Content: Wow Jeff...looks as though you are well on your way to 100% recovery. I'm about 5 weeks post and feel 100% aside from a little ED as well as a tiny bit of belly pain when I over due things. I remember having some nasty ass spasms too...I found breathing my way thru it helped a bunch. As far as the catheter...I had mine in for a full two weeks as recommended by my surgeon so that everything can heal properly. I was envious of all the guys on here who had it removed the first week...but looking back now, I think it may have helped with the incontinence quite a bit. I was dry at night since day one and maybe a slight dribble after a week and that was it. Anyway...congrats on a successful operation and all the best in the future!
Posts.Title: Day five, post RALP
